title: Death to the Daleks
dialogue_disasters: A Dalek contemplates a job with Group 4: 'Human prisoner has escaped. I have failed. Self-destruct!'
goofs: The Daleks practise their replacement machine guns on a model TARDIS. Where they got it from is never explained.
Bad editing at the end of episode one makes it clear that the Daleks' guns don't work.
What happened to the Exxilon in the TARDIS after Sarah knocks it out? Is it still wandering around in there?
The cliffhanger to episode three involves the city's floor trap, which the viewer doesn't even know is a trap yet.

continuity_notes.name: Parrinium
continuity_notes.description: A chemical rare on Earth but common on Exxilon, used to cure space plague.
continuity_notes.current_status: Needed to save millions of lives on outer planets and colonies.

continuity_notes.name: Daleks
continuity_notes.description: Cyborg aliens, sworn enemies of the Doctor.
continuity_notes.current_status: Using a 'scorched planet policy' and moving their casings by psychokinetic power.

continuity_notes.name: Exxilons
continuity_notes.description: Ancient alien race that influenced Earth civilizations.
continuity_notes.current_status: Nearly wiped out by their own creation, the living City.

technobabble: Parrinium is a chemical that is rare on Earth but is as common as salt on Exxilon: it's also the cure for the space plague, which was caused by the Daleks' 'plague missiles'.
The Daleks move their casings by psychokinetic power.
roots: The Doctor sings 'Oh I Do Like to Be Beside the Seaside'
links: The story continues directly from 'Invasion of the Dinosaurs'

locations.name: Exxilon
locations.description: An ancient planet with a living City that nearly wiped out its creators.

future_history: Stewart's group are members of the Marine Space Corps.
bottom_line: A confused story with, for once, too much rather than too little plot. There really doesn't seem any need to have the Daleks in it at all. There are some adequate sacrifice scenes for Sarah to scream in, but the production seems tired and insipid, Terry Nation signposting his forthcoming interest in plague (Survivors).
